titleStmt.title: Mental Health and Quality of Life in Patients with Chronic Liver Disease: A Single-Center Structural Equation Model

analytic.title: Mental Health and Quality of Life in Patients with Chronic Liver Disease: A Single-Center Structural Equation Model

application.desc: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

div.head: Background
div.p: Chronic liver disease (CLD) is one of the leading disease burdens in Pakistan. Until now, there has only been limited focus in the country on providing health services through tertiary services in urban cities, whereas there is almost no research in Pakistan on the mental health and quality of life of CLD patients. This study aimed to understand which predictors in uence the mental health and quality of life of CLD patients in order to advise better policy protection.

div.head: Methods
div.p: Data was collected from CLD patients at the Pakistan Kidney and Liver Institute and Research Centre, Lahore, Pakistan. A total of 850 respondents were part of the nal sample.

div.head: Results
div.p: Mean results reveal that female as well as illiterate patients need more support for mental health and communication with their physician; whereas men need more support to develop coping strategies.

Structural equation modelling results reveal that the severity of symptoms (β = 0.24, p < 0.001), coping strategies (β=-0.51, p < 0.001), and doctor communication (β=-0.35, p < 0.001) predict mental health.
Quality of life is associated with the severity of symptoms (β=-0.36, p < 0.001), coping strategies (β = 0.26, p < 0.05), and doctor communication (β = 0.09, p < 0.05).

div.head: Conclusions
div.p: A 'bio-psycho-social-spiritual' model is recommended for Pakistan's CLD patients which includes the integration of social o cers to provide support in four key areas to secure mental health and quality of life of patients.

div.head: BACKGROUND
div.p: Chronic liver disease (CLD) has become one of the most signi cant concerns of public health worldwide and is known to be one of the leading causes of death in the developing world [1]. Exact statistics for mortality, disability-adjusted life years, and years of life lost are not available for regions like Asia and Africa due to absence of accurate data and lack of coordinated efforts for data collection [2]. From the data that is available in Pakistan, estimates suggest that CLD is a major health challenge in the country but with very little policy attention and investment for prevention or disease management yet [3]. Most of the studies conducted in Pakistan are hospital-based studies with small sample sizes and there is lack of community-based data or con rmed national data about the actual prevalence of CLD [4]. However, CLD has been classi ed as the fth most common cause of morbidity and mortality in Pakistan and the country has been labelled by some as a "cirrhotic state" [5].

Globally, there is great concern about the lack of support for mental health in patients suffering from CLD [6], and their quality of life [7]. In Pakistan speci cally, there is even greater concern as mental health is not a priority area for the health sector [8], and the 'bio-psycho-social-spiritual model' [9] which is important to secure the quality of life in patients is less understood or integrated in the health system [10]. It is thus that patients holistic care with regard to integrated and multidimensional care including clinical attention, social support, and spiritual wellbeing are less considered. With gaps in statistics and limited efforts in Pakistan remaining focused on delivering services to diagnosed patients of CLD in urban zones [11], there is limited empirical evidence about the mental health and quality of life of CLD patients. The aim of this study is to identify which predictors in uence the mental health and quality of life of CLD patients in order to advise better policy protection for patients as they receive health services and support from family and providers. Structural equation modelling is less used in health research [12], even though it has bene ts over the multivariate statistical techniques [13] Quality of life in patients of CLD is affected primarily by the severity of symptoms, long period of treatment, and overall burden of care management [14,15]. Common physical symptoms of patients with CLD include fatigue, inability to function at work, loss of appetite; and abdominal pain and swelling [16],

along with personality changes such as loss of self-esteem, preference to remain isolated, and unwillingness to continue seeking health services [17,18]. Patients of CLD are also known to suffer from common mental health challenges including anxiety, depression, constant worry, and even suicide ideation [19]. As severity of symptoms progresses in patients of CLD, their mental health and quality of life are known to decline [20]. Conversely, the occurrence of depressive indicators has an adverse impact on the progression of illness, reduced compliance with treatment, and quality of life [21,22]. Previous research also con rms that high levels of anxiety and depression are experienced by patients suffering from various liver diseases in Pakistan [23].

Effective doctor communication plays a salient role in CLD patients and their mental health and quality of life [24]. Comfort with doctor relations and good communication with physicians is known to facilitate increased awareness and understanding about the disease, timely check-up and testing, and compliance for health recovery [25]. Patients who do not have good communication with their physicians are known to suffer from additional stress and anxiety [26]. Local studies con rm that compliance of patients is strongly linked to empathetic communication and information sharing of doctors [27]. Previous research stresses that physicians need support for training in communication skills to improve quality services for patients and that training needs are compromised due to low investment and prioritization by the health administration [28].

CLD management and recovery has a signi cant relationship with the patient's overall quality of life [14,29]. Along with the physical deterioration, and mental health impact, patients can suffer from socioeconomic problems such as nancial issues, lack of support from family and friends, and inability to continue with work [30,31]. Some studies also highlight that low quality of life is associated with the stage of disease or number of symptoms, the level of liver function, and the extent of social support in patients [32]. In the aftermath of the COVID-19 pandemic, CLD patients have known to suffer a greater decline in quality of life due to a lack of clarity about how to manage their disease during the lockdown and how to deal with infection and vaccination protocols [33]. The theoretical model for this study which is based on the previously described literature is summarized in Fig. 1.

div.head: Research questions and study hypotheses
div.p: Much has been written about the causes of CLD, early screening, and preventive measures [34]. However, there is less research about the management and support of patients with CLD [35]. CLD is a progressive illness with high incidence of comorbidity, leading to decline in mental health and quality of life, necessitating holistic patient support. This study aims to bridge this gap and collect perception-based data to identify which factors determine mental health and quality of life of patients in order to propose better support and interventions. The research questions for this study are:

(1) Which sociodemographic characteristics of patients with CLD, including age, gender, and literacy, are associated with severity of symptoms, coping strategies, doctor communication, mental health, and quality of life?
(2) What is the relationship between independent study constructs of severity of symptoms, coping strategies, doctor communication with dependent variables of mental health and quality of life.

The following research hypotheses are tested in this study: H1: Mental health has a positive relationship with severity of symptoms and a negative relationship with coping strategies and doctor communication. The higher the disease symptoms, the greater the mental health challenges faced by patients of liver disease. The higher the coping strategies and the better the doctor communication, the lesser the mental health challenges faced. H2: Quality of life has a negative relationship with severity of symptoms and a positive relationship with coping strategies and doctor communication. The greater the disease symptoms, the lesser the quality of life for patients of liver disease. The higher the coping strategies and the better the doctor communication, the better the quality of life.

div.head: Research design
div.p: The study collected quantitative data, based on patients' perceptions, through a closed-ended survey from the Pakistan Kidney and Liver Institute and Research Centre (PKLI), Lahore, Pakistan, which is a single public center dedicated for patients with liver diseases. Since its inception in December 2017, it has served 3.5 million patients, and almost 80% of them have received free or subsidized treatment [36]. Data was collected between May and August 2022 by experienced eld researchers who were trained over a period of two weeks by the authors of this study. The survey was translated to Urdu, the local language through the forward and backward method by authors who are bilingual in English and Urdu [37]. All data was collected in a private space provided by PKLI with data collectors assisting illiterate and semi-literate respondents for survey completion. The data has been analysed using SPSS and AMOS, considering a pvalues less than 0.05 as signi cant.

div.head: Severity of symptoms
div.p: For this study, severity of symptoms is measured based on scores for three areas according to the Chronic Liver Disease Questionnaire [38]: Fatigue, abdominal symptoms, and systemic symptoms. A seven-point Likert scale was used to measure responses ranging from 'All the time' to 'None of the time'.

Fatigue has been measured for this study using the following three items: 'How much of the time have you been tired or fatigued during the last two weeks?', 'How much of the time in the last two weeks have you been bothered by having decreased strength?', and 'How often during the last two weeks have you felt a decreased level of energy?'.

Abdominal symptoms have been measured using the following three items: 'How much of the time during the last two weeks have you been troubled by a feeling of abdominal bloating?', 'How much of the time during the last two weeks have you experienced abdominal pain?' and 'How much of the time during the last two weeks have you been troubled by a feeling of abdominal discomfort?' Systemic symptoms have been measured using the following three items: 'How much of the time during the last two weeks has shortness of breath been a problem for you in your daily activities?', 'How much of the time during the last two weeks have you been unable to fall asleep at night?', and 'How much of the time have you been troubled by itching during the last two weeks?'

div.head: Coping strategies
div.p: We used the COPE Inventory to measure coping [39]. Four items were used to measure religious coping: 'I seek God's help', 'I put my trust in God', 'I try to nd comfort in my religion', and 'I pray more than usual'. Three items were used to measure active coping and language was modi ed to suit the study: 'I take action to try to get the help I need', 'I concentrate my efforts on doing something about my disease', and 'I take measures to gain health/recovery'. Three items were used to measure planning strategies and language was modi ed to suit the study: 'I try to come up with a strategy about what to do next to gain recovery/ health stability', 'I have a plan of action to manage my illness', and 'I think about how I might best handle my health problems'. A four-point Likert scale was used to measure responses ranging from 'I usually do this a lot' to 'I usually don't do this at all'.

div.head: Doctor communication
div.p: We used the QUOTE-liver scale to measure doctor communication quality [40]. The following three areas were measured: Knowledge, interaction and care. Knowledge was measured using the following three items: 'Doctor is knowledgeable', 'Answers all questions', and 'Gives enough information about your disease/treatment'. Interaction was measured using the following three items: 'Takes you seriously', 'Makes you feel safe', and 'Takes enough time for you'. Care was measured using the following three items: 'Takes time to discuss emotional issues', 'Refers you well when you present with complaints that are not liver disease related', and 'Listens to you'. A four-point Likert scale was used to measure responses ranging from 'Yes', 'Not really', 'Mostly Yes' to 'No'.

div.head: Mental health
div.p: We used the Instrument for Common Mental Disorders to measure mental health [41]. Four sub-domains were included: Illness worry, anxiety, general fear and hopelessness, and depression. Illness worry was measured using the following three items: 'Worry that there is something seriously wrong with your body', 'Worry about health all the time', and 'Thoughts that the doctor may be wrong in telling you not to worry'. Anxiety was measured using the following three items: 'Feeling suddenly scared for no reason', 'Nervousness or shakiness inside', and 'Spells of terror and panic'. General fear and hopelessness was measured using the following three items: 'Feeling fearful', 'Feeling hopeless about the future', and 'Feeling everything is an effort'. Depression was measured using the following three items: 'Feelings of worthlessness', 'Thoughts of ending life' and 'feelings of being trapped or caught'. A ve-point Likert scale was used to measure responses ranging from 'Not at all' to 'Extremely'.

div.head: Quality of life
div.p: We used the brief WHOQOL survey to measure quality of life in CLD patients [42]. General quality of life was measured using three items: 'How satis ed are you with the quality of your life?', 'In general, how satis ed you with your life?', and 'How satis ed are you with your health?'. Level of independence was measured using the following three items: 'How satis ed are you with your ability to perform your daily living activities?', 'How satis ed are you with your capacity for work?', and 'How satis ed are you with your ability to move around?'. A ve-point Likert scale was used to measure responses ranging from 'Very dissatis ed' to 'Very satis ed'.

div.head: Reliability analysis
div.p: The Cronbach's alpha (α) results for study variables have been reported in Table 1. All study variables have satisfactory Cronbach's alpha values above 0.700 [43].

div.head: Sociodemographic characteristics
div.p: Table 2 summarizes the sociodemographic characteristics of participants. The majority of the 850 respondents of this study are above the age of 40 years (73.2%) and married (83.4%). The sample is split almost evenly between men and women and the majority has a monthly household income of USD 22.20-221.00 (66.7%), suggesting that most of the sample is from the lower middle class of Pakistan. Very few of the respondents have a graduate degree or above (14.7%) and few are currently employed (33.6%).

div.head: Prevalence of common mental health disorders
div.p: Respondents reported experiences in facing common mental health disorders (Fig. 2). The majority of CLD patients suffered from high incidence of worry about health overall (94.9%). Almost all patients felt that everything they do is an effort (90.9%) and felt blue or sad (89.4%). The majority also experienced loneliness (81.5%), fear (74.9%), and worthlessness (70.0%). More than half of respondents were hopeless about the future (66.1%) and felt trapped (63.3%). Of most concern is that almost half of CLD patients had thoughts of ending their life (36.5%).

div.head: Mean comparisons
div.p: Mean results for age and study variables are presented in Table 3a. None of the results are signi cant.

div.head: Correlation analysis
div.p: Pearson correlation results (Table 4) show that mental health is positively correlated with severity of symptoms (r = 0.288, p < 0.005) and negatively correlated with coping strategies (r=-0.243, p < 0.005), doctor communication (r=-0.258, p < 0.005), and quality of life (r=-0.297, p < 0.005).

div.head: Structural equation
div.p: The Chi square test (χ2 = 2.26, p < 0.05) and goodness of t index (GFI = 0.965) demonstrated a good model t. The alternate t indices con rmed the acceptable t of the sample (CFI = 0.983, AGFI = 0.950, RMSEA = 0.070).

All the coe cients between mental health and quality of life, and the three observed variables were found to be signi cant (Fig. 3). The results show that the three observed variables of severity of symptoms (β = 0.242, p < 0.001), coping strategies (β=-0.505, p < 0.001), and doctor communication (β=-0.352, p < 0.001), signi cantly explain mental health in patients of CLD. Similarly, the three observed variables of severity of symptoms (β=-0.363, p < 0.001), coping strategies (β = 0.258, p < 0.05), and doctor communication (β = 0.094, p < 0.05), signi cantly explain quality of life in patients of CLD.

div.head: DISCUSSION
div.p: With Pakistan's high incidence of CLD burden, PKLI is playing a critical role in providing free and subsidized services to majority poor patients in the country who do not have out-of-pocket expenses [44].

Our ndings show that women patients suffering from CLD have less communication with doctors and suffer from greater mental health challenges. It may be that women from more disadvantaged, semiliterate or illiterate backgrounds, and those belonging to conservative families have less ability to communicate and interact with physicians [45]. It may also be that doctors communicate less with female patients due to issues of 'cultural con ict', and perceptions that women complain more or misrepresent symptoms [46]. Other studies have also found that female CLD patients suffer from greater mental health disorders compared to male patients [47,48]. This may be because women have less social support and face more stigma in Pakistani society when they suffer from a chronic disease [49].
Furthermore, women may also have more fears and anxiety when facing chronic disease burden due to their inability to continue care and nurturing for family, children, and other dependents [50].

Similarly, our results also show that illiterate patients suffering from CLD have less communication with physicians and suffer from greater mental health challenges. Other studies con rm that illiterate patients face problems in understanding medical vocabulary, reading prescriptions and physician's instructions, and understanding patient education pamphlets and instructions for revisits and further tests [51]. A study conducted in Pakistan con rms that illiterate patients of CLD gain less information from doctor consultations and have low knowledge about how to manage disease and diet, consequently leading to adverse health results [52]. Another local study reports that illiterate patients suffering from CLD experience higher incidence of depression [53]. Anxiety and stress in illiterate populations of CLD has been found to be high due to lack of awareness and clarity, misconceptions and myths, and language barriers about disease [54].

Our results also show that men have fewer coping strategies pertaining to religion, active behaviour, and planning for disease management. Another study con rms that women are better at adopting coping strategies during illness, as they are more comfortable in showing emotions, turning to religion, and dealing with challenges by using social support [55]. Comparatively, men are less inclined to turn to religion or exhibit the emotions needed for adaptive coping during illness [56]. Patients of CLD are not always hospitalized or in doctor consultations, and thus development of self-care and coping strategies are integral to maintain their quality of life and mental health [57].

With regard to our rst hypothesis, the study ndings con rm that mental health of patients with CLD has a signi cant and positive relationship with severity of symptoms and a negative relationship with coping strategies and doctor communication. The second hypothesis of the study is also proven correct, and quality of life of patients with CLD has a signi cant and negative relationship with severity of symptoms and a positive relationship with coping strategies and doctor communication. Our ndings con rm research from the developed world and that the management of patients with CLD is incomplete without interventions to improve and maintain mental health [19] and quality of life [58]. Based on the ndings of this study, ve areas need to be urgently addressed to improve the mental health and quality of life of CLD patients.

First, the management of severity of symptoms needs to be improved effectively through improved surveillance of high-risk groups at early stage and in primary settings [59]. Early treatment and effective lifestyle changes are needed for CLD patients of Pakistan [60], which is a partnership between the health sector, the patient, and their family. The support of the family and awareness and willingness of the patient to seek early treatment and commit to weight reduction, improved physical activity and better nutrition can play an integral role in preventing advancement of symptoms [71]. The unfavourable doctor to patient ratio, estimated at 1:1,300, also needs to be improved to support doctor communication and e ciency [72]. Supervision of doctor communication with patients by independent bodies in the hospital setting can be an important means of providing support to both the patient for better quality care and the doctor who can share needs and concerns about role burden or lack of administrative support [73]. Health sector regulatory bodies who have used patient satisfaction questionnaires to assess communication skills of providers, have been able to develop an effective action plan for improved healthcare services [74]. Social workers and social policy o cers working in the hospital setting have been found to be useful partners in supporting doctors for improved communication and decision-making for patients [75].

Fourth, mental healthcare services and counseling of CLD patients must be introduced in the tertiary institutes of Pakistan [76]. Our study found that the prevalence of mental health disorders in CLD patients is very high, including feelings of worry, sadness, loneliness, and fear for the future. Other local scholarship con rms that mental health in CLD patients is a considerable challenge [77], but this study has determined statistical frequencies for different mental health disorders which highlight the need for early screening and management. Of great concern is that suicide ideation has been indicated by a signi cant number of CLD patients in our sample. Given that Pakistani society is known to underreport suicide due to religious and cultural reasons [78], it may be that suicide ideation prevalence is even greater than what is indicated in this study. Not only is integration of mental health services by counsellors essential at tertiary level for CLD patients [79], but there is need for mental health services to be designed according to the cultural and religious beliefs for improved uptake [80]. Social workers and social policy o cers have been found to be effective in providing mental healthcare support to patients as they are trained to manage cultural differences and provide religiously sensitive services [81].

Finally, health literacy for CLD patients is integral as the disease is complex and even educated patients need awareness and support for disease management. As mentioned earlier, Pakistani CLD patients suffer from backgrounds of low literacy and there is no support for health literacy in the hospital setting.
Studies have found that the integration of social case workers in the hospital team can improve health literacy in patients leading to better health outcomes [82].

div.head: CONCLUSIONS
div.p: This study is limited to a single center sample and is not representative of the entire nation. We recommend future studies to sample other provinces and to attempt longitudinal intervention-based research to assess the impact of improved care plans for patients with CLD. However, this study is an important contribution to the limited research about CLD patients who need support for mental health and quality of life. Given that Pakistan is a developing nation with low allocation of health budget, ine cient governance and planning, and a large rural and impoverished population, it is imperative to design prudent interventions for CLD patients using culture-speci c and self-care initiatives. Early treatment and effective lifestyle changes are essential to manage severity of symptoms. Mental health service models which are culturally appropriate and regionally accepted need to be considered. The study also highlights that female patients of CLD need support through female HCPs and female coordinators at health centers for better communication and compliance. Self-care programs and education for adopting coping strategies related to religion and spirituality, active behaviour, and planning for disease management and recovery are also needed. Education of medical students and continued training of physicians is needed for improved patient-doctor communication overall, and speci c doctor training for gender sensitization and support for illiterate patients. Finally, the overburdened and understaffed healthcare provider teams at hospital settings and tertiary sector of Pakistan must be reinforced and made more e cient through the integration of social policy o cers or social workers.

note.p: Mean results for gender and study variables are presented in Table3b. Signi cant results show that women have higher coping strategies (4.24 vs. 3.91, p < 0.001), less communication with doctor (12.86 vs. 13.36, p < 0.001), and suffer from greater problems related to mental health (9.98 vs. 9.14, p < 0.005) compared to men.Mean results for literacy and study variables are presented in Table3c. Signi cant results show that illiterate patients have less communication with doctor (12.57 vs. 14.03, p < 0.001), and suffer from greater problems related to mental health (10.71 vs. 8.64, p < 0.001) compared to literate ones.

row.cell: Quality of life is negatively correlated with severity of symptoms (r=-0.220, p < 0.005). Though quality of
life is positively correlated with coping strategies and doctor communication, the results are not

figure.figDesc: [61]. Scholarship asserts that managing symptoms of CLD patients and preventing or delaying progression requires intensive surveillance and individually tailored therapeutic approaches, which is only possible through joint efforts by the provider, patient and support network including family and friends[62, 63]. A systematic literature review con rms the integral role of social workers or social policy o cers in being integrated in the hospital team and managing the psychosocial aspects of CLD patients and progression of symptoms [64]. Second, CLD patients need to be supported for religious and spiritual coping, as well as in the development of active and planning coping behaviours. Numerous interventions which include emotional support, self-distraction, positive reframing, and acceptance [65] have been used to develop coping skills in patients with CLD, with the role of religious coping shown to be the most effective in Pakistan [66]. Developing coping strategies suited to the individual depends on early screening of personality behaviour and life circumstances and requires the support of a counsellor [67]. Recommended steps for developing coping behaviours in chronically ill people includes assisting patients in expressing grief, providing opportunities to seek personal meaning, and training to gain mastery in managing emptions and challenges, which are best achieved through a combination of support from the counsellor, social worker, provider, and family members [68]. Other research con rms that religious leaders and notables can play an integral role in addressing challenges of the chronically ill and supporting patients with spiritual coping [69]. Third, training for doctor communication skills needs to be improved and maintained as a continued learning model. Studies show that doctors have less interest in continued learning for communication skills due to excessive workload and preference for expanding or updating medical knowledge [70]. It is thus important for health administration to ensure mandatory and continued training, and to ensure providers gain the relevant communication skills needed for different patients, as hepatocellular carcinoma patients may require different communication methods compared to patients with cirrhosis

Table 5 summarizes what has been discussed above and recommends a 'bio-psycho-social-spiritual model' to improve mental health and quality of life among CLD patients in Pakistan. This model can be managed by a social worker or social protection o cer in the tertiary setting, who are known to be successful patient case managers on interdisciplinary disease management teams [83].

div.head: Acknowledgements
div.p: We are extremely grateful to the PKLI administration and coordinators for their support during data collection. This research would not have been possible without the time and commitment of our students, who spent long hours travelling to PKLI and collecting data from each respondent, with each survey taking 35 to 40 minutes. At times the students had to wait all day or many hours waiting for patients to have some free time in between visits with their doctor. They collected data and supported respondents with empathy and compassion, and they worked without funding and compensation. We are deeply indebted to each and every one of them including the following: (i) Nine students from LCWU: Farwa Ashfaq; Sana Shahid; Ayesha Ishfaq; Uswa Ziyad; Nimra Riaz; Komal Riaz; Fatima-tul-Zahra; Dua Fatima; and Mariam Zul qar; (ii) Six students from Kinnaird College: Tania Waseem; Fajar Rizwan; Emen Ali; Iffa Irshad; Shagufta Ashraf; and Adeena Sohail; and (iii) Thirteen students from UCP: Siddiqa Allah Yar; Farwa Malik; Zoha Aziz; Muzhdah Hasan; Rehab Ali; Muhammad Natiq; Kinza Kaleem; Sawera Khadim; Aiza Humayun; Safa Jamil; Javeria Iftikhar; Rija Shahzad; and Rabia Saeed.

div.head: Funding
div.p: This has not received funding.

div.head: Data
div.p: Data is available from corresponding author upon reasonable request.

div.head: Competing interests
div.p: The authors declare that they have no competing interests Authors' contribution SRJ, AN and HA conceptualized this project and developed the tool for data collection. SKB, AK, and MAK supervised the data collection. SRJ conducted the data analysis and drafted the manuscript. All authors revised the manuscript for important intellectual content and agreed on the nal version.
